meta: • The Turkish letters "ş", "ç" and "ı" are pronounced like English "sh", "ch" and the "a" in "above". • The letters i and ı represent different vowels. • The letters u and ü represent different vowels, rather like the difference between the vowel sound in "foot" as opposed to "food" or "boot". • The letter "ğ" is usually silent (like the "gh" in "although").
train: My friends [are] happy in the city.
Poor people want to come from [the city of] Van to Istanbul.
My father says 'Hello! Come and be our friend'.
There are big windows in our house
Do you want to buy [a] house?
test: My friend wants to (be/become) a doctor
Do they like my poor house?
(Are you coming/Do you come) from Istanbul?
(Is your father happy that we (came/come/are coming)/(Does/Did) your father like us to come)?
Is the house (that/which) you (bought/are buying) big?
((The/A) city where I am happiest is Van/Van is (the/a) city where I am happiest)
(Although we are poor, we are happy/In spite of our being poor, we are happy).
